Bash(git commit -m "$(cat <<''EOF''
Week 11-01: Hardcoded Input ANTI-PATTERN demonstration

âŒ PROBLEM: Hardcoded key bindings and tight coupling

This branch demonstrates the problems with hardcoded input handling:
- InputHandler has giant if-else chain with hardcoded WASD keys
- Tightly coupled to Player class
- Impossible to remap keys without modifying code
- Cannot implement undo, macros, or key rebinding
- Violates Open/Closed Principle

New Features:
- Player-controlled movement with WASD + Enter (Windows limitation)
- Collision detection: Player vs Coins and Obstacles
- Collision detection: Obstacle vs Obstacle (no overlap)
- Double buffering rendering (reduced flickering)
- HUD integrated with buffering (no screen jumping)
- Balanced gameplay (Wolf speed: 1.0, spawn rate: 2/sec)
- Hidden cursor during gameplay

Technical Implementation:
- Entity interface for polymorphism (Player/NPC)
- Player class with health and movement
- InputHandler with hardcoded key bindings (ANTI-PATTERN)
- GridRenderer with double buffering and cursor hiding
- Object Pool pattern (carried from Week 10)

Limitations:
- Windows console requires Enter after each key (System.in buffered input)
- Input echo may be visible (terminal-dependent)
- Map may scroll on Enter (Windows console limitation)

Teaching Points:
- This is an ANTI-PATTERN - demonstrates WHY we need Command Pattern
- Hardcoded keys are inflexible and hard to maintain
- Tight coupling makes testing and extension difficult
- Next branch (11-02) will show Command Pattern as solution

ðŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
)")

Week 11-01: Finalize Hardcoded Input ANTI-PATTERN demonstration

âŒ PROBLEM: Hardcoded key bindings and tight coupling

This branch demonstrates the problems with hardcoded input handling:
- InputHandler has giant if-else chain with hardcoded WASD keys
- Tightly coupled to Player class
- Impossible to remap keys without modifying code
- Cannot implement undo, macros, or key rebinding
- Violates Open/Closed Principle

New Features:
- Player-controlled movement with WASD + Enter (Windows limitation)
- Collision detection: Player vs Coins and Obstacles
- Collision detection: Obstacle vs Obstacle (no overlap)
- Double buffering rendering (reduced flickering)
- HUD integrated with buffering (no screen jumping)
- Balanced gameplay (Wolf speed: 1.0, spawn rate: 2/sec)
- Hidden cursor during gameplay

Technical Implementation:
- Entity interface for polymorphism (Player/NPC)
- Player class with health and movement
- InputHandler with hardcoded key bindings (ANTI-PATTERN)
- GridRenderer with double buffering
- Object Pool pattern (carried from Week 10)

Windows Console Limitations (Documented):
- Requires Enter after each key (System.in buffered input)
- Input echo may be visible (terminal-dependent)
- Cannot achieve raw unbuffered input without JNI
- Real games use native libraries or game engines

Teaching Points:
- This is an ANTI-PATTERN - demonstrates WHY we need Command Pattern
- Hardcoded keys are inflexible and hard to maintain
- Tight coupling makes testing and extension difficult
- Next branch (11-02) will show Command Pattern as solution
